awd_titl_txt: CC* Storage: Robust Persistent Identification of Data (RPID)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses upon robust, persistent identification of data, which could greatly improve scientific discovery and reuse of datasets.    Persistent identifiers of data (PIDs) enhance scientific discovery and are an important element of research data sharing.  This project creates a testbed to evaluate new capabilities for persistent identifiers.  The initial stage of the project will include four diverse repositories containing millions of PIDs, and the second stage will allow any NSF-eligible institution to use the testbed to evaluate their own work.  The project would enhance research interoperability.

Currently, there are several persistent identifier options for data (such as Digital Object Identifiers, Handles, the Archive Resource Key, and Uniform Resource Names).   The existing environment is limited by multiple solutions, weak interoperability, and procedures translating PID to data object that are inconsistent.  This project provides several new capabilities:
 - A testbed to research new capabilities and interoperability for persistent identifiers, which builds upon Indiana University cyberinfrastructure and instances on Amazon Web Services;
 - The ability to prototype and evaluate PID types, allowing study of the difficulties and advantages of relating types to one another across a distributed system; and
 - Approaches to mapping from PIDs to Canonical Text Services Uniform Resource Names (CTS URNs).  Combining URNs with Handles should allow a precise CTS URN referencing capability, with the flexible resolution of the existing widely-used Handle System.
The goal is to standardize the results of PID resolution, allowing various PID services to interoperate at a higher level.

por.por_cntn:
The Robust Persistent Identification of Data (RPID) project established a testbed of online services that allow users and developers of data repositories to have data objects in the repositories be more easily:

1. Identified with globally unique long-term identifiers (PIDs);
2. Associated with key metadata about the identified entities, and;
3. Associated with data types and pre-defined operations explicitly connected to those data types for increased machine processing and interoperability.

The testbed was deployed on hardware at Indiana University and on Amazon Web Services, and was packaged with the Puppet Configuration Management tools to allow adoption and evaluation. The testbed services were then used to evaluate the use of a small kernel of metadata associated with each PID record to allow high-level filtering of the data content. This allows requests for data sets to be reduced to the necessary records for a given task by evaluating the small identifier records rather than retrieving each large data set and then deciding whether or not it is relevant for the given task. The metadata kernel associated with each PID can also be used to establish trust and provenance. Long-term, this technology could greatly simplify the development time for research projects that utilize multiple heterogeneous data sources for their research.    

    The project conducted four diverse use cases (on environmental sensor data, rice genomics data, classical literature texts, and virtual machine images on an academic cloud computing environment)  to evaluate RPID services. For the environmental sensor use case, the team created a web portal that allowed high-level sorting, which is still being utilized. The rice genomic use case involved using provenance data to establish a tracking system for the data throughout its analysis life cycle. In the case of the classical texts, the team proposed a solution for mapping the currently-used unique resource names (URNs) to PIDs in order to provide global resolution, a capability not provided by URNs. Finally, the virtual machine images use case provided a possible approach to the reproducibility of data analyses.

  The project also established an international User Advisory Group of 18 experts in the PID and cyberinfrastructure communities to provide feedback on evaluation and adoption activities. This set of experts provided feedback that proved key to community impact, and will continue to provide feedback even after this project ends, offering an ongoing contribution to PID-related cyberinfrastructure research.

The RPID project successfully deployed a stable set of testbed services that will remain in use through the calendar year of 2020, provided significant value to each of the four use cases, and established a user advisory group that will continue to advise the project into the future. At the same time, it also provided a realistic picture to the research data community of the services needed, the effort of implementing these services, and the necessity of a community-centered approach for data-centric operations to become a reality. This approach to data-centric operations allows researchers to reduce the time spent manipulating data into a usable form for analysis, and to establish a sense of trust in the data they choose to use for their research. It also provides a continuing testbed for future research on adoption of this cyberinfrastructure.
